intro: Tetraena gaetula subsp. waterlotii, commonly known as the Canary Island rock rose, is a flowering plant native to the Canary Islands. It is a shrub that typically grows in coastal and rocky habitats, characterized by its small, woody stems and evergreen leaves. The plant produces clusters of fragrant, pink or white flowers during the spring and summer months. It is adapted to withstand saline and arid conditions, making it a resilient species in its native environment. Its botanical features reflect its evolutionary adaptation to the unique ecological conditions of the Canary Islands.
